channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00298-z

Best practice for LGBTQ+ data collection by STEM organizations

Tyler L. Kelly

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00300-8

Urban trees: how to maximize their benefits for humans and the environment
item.dc:title: Urban trees: how to maximize their benefits for humans and the environment
item.dc:creator: Lina Tang
Guofan Shao
Peter M. Groffman

item.title: From the archive: lonely cells, and Thomas Henry Huxley backs evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00235-0

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: lonely cells, and Thomas Henry Huxley backs evolution

item.title: ‘Bee protection’ offsets are as flawed as tree-planting schemes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00299-y

‘Bee protection’ offsets are as flawed as tree-planting schemes
item.dc:title: ‘Bee protection’ offsets are as flawed as tree-planting schemes
item.dc:creator: Ainhoa Magrach

item.title: Clinical trials: Japan’s opt-out policy raises risks of adverse drug responses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00301-7

Clinical trials: Japan’s opt-out policy raises risks of adverse drug responses
item.dc:title: Clinical trials: Japan’s opt-out policy raises risks of adverse drug responses
item.dc:creator: Mira Namba
Yudai Kaneda
Akihiko Ozaki
Tetsuya Tanimoto

item.title: ‘Altruistic’ bull elephant seal lends a helping flipper
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00319-x

Male elephant seals generally have nothing to do with pups — but astounded scientists observed a notable exception.
item.dc:title: ‘Altruistic’ bull elephant seal lends a helping flipper

item.title: Santorini’s volcanic past: underwater clues reveal giant prehistoric eruption
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00326-y

An expedition that drilled into the sea floor near the famous Greek island found signs of a gargantuan blast 520,000 years ago and more recent eruptions.
item.dc:title: Santorini’s volcanic past: underwater clues reveal giant prehistoric eruption
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: EU unveils controversial climate target: what scientists think
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00361-9

The goal leans heavily on the largely unproven approach of carbon removal, concerning researchers.
item.dc:title: EU unveils controversial climate target: what scientists think
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson
Carissa Wong

item.title: Why the mental cost of a STEM career can be too high for women and people of colour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00324-0

Under-represented groups face chronic barriers, creating psychological — and physical — effects. The scientific community must ease this burden.
item.dc:title: Why the mental cost of a STEM career can be too high for women and people of colour
item.dc:creator: Jean King

item.title: Active fluids navigate networks by solving sudoku-like problems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00277-4

Networks filled with self-propelled fluids display meandering patterns that have been shown to follow rules similar to those of sudoku puzzles — offering design principles for microfluidic devices, and the possibility of ‘active fluid’ logic.
item.dc:title: Active fluids navigate networks by solving sudoku-like problems
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Le Verge-Serandour
Karen Alim

item.title: No ‘easy’ weight loss: don’t overlook the social cost of anti-obesity drugs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00329-9

Ideas of diet and exercise as the ‘best’ way to lose weight could stigmatize people taking Ozempic, WeGovy and other blockbuster drugs that affect appetite. Lessons from weight-loss surgery reveal ways to help.
item.dc:title: No ‘easy’ weight loss: don’t overlook the social cost of anti-obesity drugs
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Brewis
Sarah Trainer

item.title: Open science — embrace it before it’s too late
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00322-2

A UNESCO report laments the lack of progress in making science more collaborative. Greater awareness could aid efforts to achieve the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals.
item.dc:title: Open science — embrace it before it’s too late

item.title: Economists count the cost of ‘risky’ science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00360-w

A survey seeks to define risk in research and how academics approach it in their work.
item.dc:title: Economists count the cost of ‘risky’ science
item.dc:creator: Chris Woolston

item.title: CERN’s supercollider plan: $17-billion ‘Higgs factory’ would dwarf LHC
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00353-9

A feasibility study on the Future Circular Collider identifies where and how the machine could be built — but its construction is far from a done deal.
item.dc:title: CERN’s supercollider plan: $17-billion ‘Higgs factory’ would dwarf LHC
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney
Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: How population size shapes the evolution of guppy fish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00276-5

A long-term fish experiment reveals how a mechanism called density dependence, in which the population growth rate slows as the number of individuals rises, affects population dynamics on time scales relevant for ecology and evolution.
item.dc:title: How population size shapes the evolution of guppy fish
item.dc:creator: Bernt-Erik Sæther

item.title: Absence of female partners can explain the dawn chorus of birds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00264-9

Why birds sing intensely in a dawn chorus during the early morning has long been debated. Evidence gathered from observing birds in the wild offers a fresh perspective on what might drive this phenomenon.
item.dc:title: Absence of female partners can explain the dawn chorus of birds
item.dc:creator: Diego Gil

item.title: AI chatbot shows surprising talent for predicting chemical properties and reactions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00347-7

Researchers lightly tweak ChatGPT-like system to offer chemistry insight.
item.dc:title: AI chatbot shows surprising talent for predicting chemical properties and reactions
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Ivory artefacts’ origins revealed by telltale peptides
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00247-w

The family, genus or even species of animal that supplied the materials for a famed museum’s objects could be identified with minimal damage to the items.
item.dc:title: Ivory artefacts’ origins revealed by telltale peptides

item.title: Surprise find: a blood-based immune system is discovered in the gut
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00245-y

Immune guardians called complement proteins are manufactured by gut cells and help to protect against pathogens.
item.dc:title: Surprise find: a blood-based immune system is discovered in the gut

item.title: I started fossil hunting in my 60s — now I have more than 2,000 pieces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00330-2

Heather Middleton trawls England’s Jurassic Coast for specimens that might lead to a deeper understanding of palaeontology.
item.dc:title: I started fossil hunting in my 60s — now I have more than 2,000 pieces
item.dc:creator: Rachael Pells

item.title: Synthesizing and identifying potential biomarkers to explore uncharted biochemistry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04105-z

Public repositories of metabolomics data are expanding rapidly and can be leveraged to uncover previously undescribed metabolites. Reverse metabolomics is a workflow in which thousands of small compounds are synthesized using combinatorial chemistry, and their molecular ‘fingerprints’ are then used to discover where they are localized in tissues and biological fluids and how they are associated with health and disease in humans.
item.dc:title: Synthesizing and identifying potential biomarkers to explore uncharted biochemistry

item.title: The world has warmed 1.5 °C, according to 300-year-old sponges
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00281-8

By the time that official temperature records began, global temperatures had already risen by half a degree.
item.dc:title: The world has warmed 1.5 °C, according to 300-year-old sponges
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: JWST is most in-demand telescope ever — leaving many astronomers in the cold
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00315-1

Reviewers will likely approve only one in every nine research proposals submitted in latest application cycle.
item.dc:title: JWST is most in-demand telescope ever — leaving many astronomers in the cold
item.dc:creator: Rahul Rao

item.title: Innovative funding systems are key to fighting inequities in African science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00348-6

A few countries and a select number of institutions will continue to take the vast majority of grants unless funders build diversity into their grant programmes.
item.dc:title: Innovative funding systems are key to fighting inequities in African science
item.dc:creator: Susan Gichoga

item.title: It’s time to admit that genes are not the blueprint for life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00327-x

The view of biology often presented to the public is oversimplified and out of date. Scientists must set the record straight, argues a new book.
item.dc:title: It’s time to admit that genes are not the blueprint for life
item.dc:creator: Denis Noble

item.title: Several transient binding events create a strong, adaptable interface between organelles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04120-0

Rapid communication between intracellular structures such as the endoplasmic reticulum and the mitochondria is crucial for the coordinated functioning of cells. Such interactions occur mainly at sites where the compartments are in direct contact, and are mediated by specific tethering machinery. High-speed single-molecule tracking reveals a well-regulated interface at which many rapid binding and unbinding events provide highly adaptable interactions.
item.dc:title: Several transient binding events create a strong, adaptable interface between organelles

item.title: First passages of rolled-up Herculaneum scroll revealed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00346-8

Researchers used artificial intelligence to decipher the text of 2,000-year-old charred papyrus scripts, unveiling musings on music and capers.
item.dc:title: First passages of rolled-up Herculaneum scroll revealed
item.dc:creator: Jo Marchant

item.title: I’m not a chatbot – I promise!
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00349-5

A journal reviewer accused Lizzie Wolkovich of using ChatGPT to write a manuscript. She hadn’t — but her paper was rejected anyway.
item.dc:title: I’m not a chatbot – I promise!
item.dc:creator: E. M. Wolkovich

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Feynman’s sprinkler’ spin mystery solved
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00356-6

If an S-shaped sprinkler sucks instead of sprays, which way does it spin? Plus, the month’s best science images and what scientists think of the Neuralink human trial.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Feynman’s sprinkler’ spin mystery solved
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Science and government: can the power struggle ever end?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00328-w

Similar goals but different strategies underlie tensions between science and the state, an in-depth analysis explains.
item.dc:title: Science and government: can the power struggle ever end?
item.dc:creator: Rhona Mijumbi

item.title: Cervical cancer could be eliminated: here’s how
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00302-6

Two experts lay out the steps that need to be taken, and the challenges facing low- and middle-income countries.
item.dc:title: Cervical cancer could be eliminated: here’s how
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Jennifer Gardiner

item.title: Author Correction: Satellite mapping reveals extensive industrial activity at sea
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07123-7

Author Correction: Satellite mapping reveals extensive industrial activity at sea
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Satellite mapping reveals extensive industrial activity at sea
item.dc:creator: Fernando S. Paolo
David Kroodsma
Jennifer Raynor
Tim Hochberg
Pete Davis
Jesse Cleary
Luca Marsaglia
Sara Orofino

item.title: The mystery of Feynman’s sprinkler is solved at last
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00246-x

A puzzle named after the Nobel-prizewinning physicist has been solved by experiments with a submerged sprinkler.
item.dc:title: The mystery of Feynman’s sprinkler is solved at last

item.title: An ancient tree’s oddball shape is revealed by an extraordinary fossil
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00317-z

Many fossilized trees consist of only the trunk, but a specimen from Canada includes most of the crown of leaves.
item.dc:title: An ancient tree’s oddball shape is revealed by an extraordinary fossil

item.title: A forgotten Aztec scholar and more: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00278-3

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: A forgotten Aztec scholar and more: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: ‘Blue foods’ to tackle hidden hunger and improve nutrition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00209-2

Aquatic foods have been overlooked in moves to end food insecurity. That needs to change, says Christopher Golden.
item.dc:title: ‘Blue foods’ to tackle hidden hunger and improve nutrition
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: Israel is flooding Gaza’s tunnel network: scientists assess the risks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00320-4

The plan to target Hamas involves filling parts of a 500-kilometre-long network of underground tunnels. Researchers warn this could affect Gaza’s water supplies.
item.dc:title: Israel is flooding Gaza’s tunnel network: scientists assess the risks
item.dc:creator: Josie Glausiusz

item.title: Crackdown on skin-colour bias by fingertip oxygen sensors is coming, hints FDA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04144-6

Devices can overestimate blood oxygen levels in people with dark skin, affecting medical care.
item.dc:title: Crackdown on skin-colour bias by fingertip oxygen sensors is coming, hints FDA
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Elon Musk’s Neuralink brain chip: what scientists think of first human trial
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00304-4

Some researchers are concerned about a lack of transparency surrounding the implant, which aims to allow people to control devices through thought alone.
item.dc:title: Elon Musk’s Neuralink brain chip: what scientists think of first human trial
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: Daily briefing: Autoimmune disease linked to X chromosome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00342-y

A molecular coating found on the X chromosome might be one of the reasons women account for around 80% of all cases of autoimmune disease. Plus, an alternative to qubits for quantum computers and how AI learns language through a baby’s eyes.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Autoimmune disease linked to X chromosome
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Building used by Marie Curie will be dismantled to erect cancer centre
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00321-3

The disused and formerly radioactive Pavillon des Sources in Paris will be rebuilt nearby, following an agreement between scientists and the French culture ministry.
item.dc:title: Building used by Marie Curie will be dismantled to erect cancer centre
item.dc:creator: Nisha Gaind

item.title: Publisher Correction: Developmental dynamics of two bipotent thymic epithelial progenitor types
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07129-1

Publisher Correction: Developmental dynamics of two bipotent thymic epithelial progenitor types
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Developmental dynamics of two bipotent thymic epithelial progenitor types
item.dc:creator: Anja Nusser
Sagar
Jeremy B. Swann
Brigitte Krauth
Dagmar Diekhoff
Lesly Calderon
Christiane Happe
Dominic Grün
Thomas Boehm

item.title: How to enhance lab-team efficiency with tools from the tech industry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00312-4

Using freely available software can help to maximize productivity and avoid collaboration pain points.
item.dc:title: How to enhance lab-team efficiency with tools from the tech industry
item.dc:creator: Lathan Liou
Akshay Swaminathan

item.title: Number of Black UK professors rises by 25% in one year
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00249-8

Initiatives such as grass-roots campaigns are likely to have contributed to the uptick, but barriers to progress remain.
item.dc:title: Number of Black UK professors rises by 25% in one year
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: In the AI science boom, beware: your results are only as good as your data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00306-2

Machine-learning systems are voracious data consumers — but trustworthy results require more vetting both before and after publication.
item.dc:title: In the AI science boom, beware: your results are only as good as your data
item.dc:creator: Hunter Moseley

item.title: Passion, curiosity and perseverance: my mission to capture women in science on camera
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00297-0

Genetics researcher Elisabetta Citterio explains why she felt compelled to photograph 57 women who work in STEM fields.
item.dc:title: Passion, curiosity and perseverance: my mission to capture women in science on camera
item.dc:creator: Josie Glausiusz

item.title: This AI learnt language by seeing the world through a baby’s eyes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00288-1

A neural network that taught itself to recognize objects using the filmed experiences of a single infant could offer new insights into how humans learn.
item.dc:title: This AI learnt language by seeing the world through a baby’s eyes
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Daily briefing: Discoveries from a huge study of mothers and babies in China
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00314-2

Landmark study of links between maternal health and fetal development is among the first to look at the genetic profiles of East Asian people. Plus, how sea otters protect shorelines from erosion and what’s behind the alarming surge of measles in Europe.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Discoveries from a huge study of mothers and babies in China
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Why autoimmune disease is more common in women: X chromosome holds clues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00267-6

Rogue antibodies are drawn to the protein–RNA coating on half of the X chromosomes in an XX cell.
item.dc:title: Why autoimmune disease is more common in women: X chromosome holds clues
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Publisher Correction: Revising the global biogeography of annual and perennial plants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07122-8

Publisher Correction: Revising the global biogeography of annual and perennial plants
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Revising the global biogeography of annual and perennial plants
item.dc:creator: Tyler Poppenwimer
Itay Mayrose
Niv DeMalach

item.title: A glacier’s ‘memory’ is fading because of climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00244-z

The environmental record preserved in ice high atop a Swiss mountain has been partially lost.
item.dc:title: A glacier’s ‘memory’ is fading because of climate change

item.title: How do otters protect salt marshes from erosion? Shellfishly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00217-2

Sea otters inadvertently protect the vegetation that binds sandy shorelines together.
item.dc:title: How do otters protect salt marshes from erosion? Shellfishly
item.dc:creator: Jude Coleman

item.title: Why human brain cells grow so slowly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00280-9

Some human neurons take years to reach maturity; an epigenetic ‘brake’ could be responsible.
item.dc:title: Why human brain cells grow so slowly
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Ancient DNA solves the mystery of who made a set of stone tools
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00290-7

Analysis of stone tools and DNA reveals when modern humans reached northern Europe, and why human brain cells grow so slowly.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA solves the mystery of who made a set of stone tools
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Stereodivergent 1,3-difunctionalization of alkenes by charge relocation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06938-0

We introduce a method for the direct 1,3-difunctionalization of alkenes, based on a concept termed ‘charge relocation’, which enables stereodivergent access to 1,3-difunctionalized products of either syn- or anti-configuration from unactivated alkenes.
item.dc:title: Stereodivergent 1,3-difunctionalization of alkenes by charge relocation
item.dc:creator: Bogdan R. Brutiu
Giulia Iannelli
Margaux Riomet
Daniel Kaiser
Nuno Maulide

item.title: Establishing reaction networks in the 16-electron sulfur reduction reaction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06918-4

We investigate the mechanism underlying the sulfur reduction reaction that plays a central role in high-capacity lithium sulfur batteries, highlighting the electrocatalytic approach as a promising strategy for tackling the fundamental challenges associated with these batteries.
item.dc:title: Establishing reaction networks in the 16-electron sulfur reduction reaction
item.dc:creator: Rongli Liu
Ziyang Wei
Lele Peng
Leyuan Zhang

item.title: Fertilizer management for global ammonia emission reduction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07020-z

A machine learning model for generating crop-specific and spatially explicit NH3 emission factors globally shows that global NH3 emissions in 2018 were lower than previous estimates that did not fully consider fertilizer management practices.
item.dc:title: Fertilizer management for global ammonia emission reduction
item.dc:creator: Peng Xu
Geng Li

item.title: 7-Dehydrocholesterol is an endogenous suppressor of ferroptosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06878-9

Proferroptotic activity of 7-dehydrocholesterol reductase is shown along with an unexpected prosurvival function of its substrate, 7-dehydrocholesterol, indicating a cell-intrinsic mechanism that could be used by cancer cells to protect phospholipids from oxidative damage and escape ferroptosis.
item.dc:title: 7-Dehydrocholesterol is an endogenous suppressor of ferroptosis

item.title: An epigenetic barrier sets the timing of human neuronal maturation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06984-8

The slow maturation of human neurons is regulated by epigenetic modification in nascent neurons, mediated by EZH2, EHMT1, EHMT2 and DOT1L.
item.dc:title: An epigenetic barrier sets the timing of human neuronal maturation

item.title: Matrix viscoelasticity promotes liver cancer progression in the pre-cirrhotic liver
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06991-9

Structural changes mediated by advanced glycation end-products enhance extracellular matrix viscoelasticity, and that viscoelasticity can promote cancer progression in vivo, independent of stiffness.
item.dc:title: Matrix viscoelasticity promotes liver cancer progression in the pre-cirrhotic liver
item.dc:creator: Weiguo Fan

item.title: Single-photon superradiance in individual caesium lead halide quantum dots
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07001-8

Excitonic single-photon superradiance is reported in individual perovskite quantum dots with a sub-100 ps radiative decay time, almost as short as the reported exciton coherence time.
item.dc:title: Single-photon superradiance in individual caesium lead halide quantum dots
item.dc:creator: Chenglian Zhu
Simon C. Boehme
Leon G. Feld
Anastasiia Moskalenko

Maksym V. Kovalenko
Gabriele Rainò

item.title: Single-neuronal elements of speech production in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06982-w

Neuropixels recordings from the language-dominant prefrontal cortex reveal a structured organization of planned words, an encoding cascade of phonetic representations by prefrontal neurons in humans and a cellular process that could support the production of speech.
item.dc:title: Single-neuronal elements of speech production in humans
item.dc:creator: Arjun R. Khanna

item.title: Oxygen-evolving photosystem II structures during S<sub>1</sub>–S<sub>2</sub>–S<sub>3</sub> transitions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06987-5

Serial femtosecond crystallography reveals the structural dynamics of photosystem II during the S-state transitions that produce dioxygen, providing insight into electron transfer, water insertion, proton release and O–O bond formation on sub-microsecond timescales.
item.dc:title: Oxygen-evolving photosystem II structures during S<sub>1</sub>–S<sub>2</sub>–S<sub>3</sub> transitions

item.title: Homo sapiens reached the higher latitudes of Europe by 45,000 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06923-7

Through archaeological excavation, morphological and proteomic taxonomic identification, mitochondrial DNA analysis and direct radiocarbon dating of human remains, a study reports the presence of Homo sapiens in Germany north of the Alps more than 45,000 years ago.
item.dc:title: Homo sapiens reached the higher latitudes of Europe by 45,000 years ago

item.title: Conformational ensembles of the human intrinsically disordered proteome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07004-5

A computational model generates conformational ensembles of 28,058 intrinsically disordered proteins and regions (IDRs) in the human proteome and sheds light on the relationship between sequence, conformational properties and functions of IDRs.
item.dc:title: Conformational ensembles of the human intrinsically disordered proteome
item.dc:creator: Giulio Tesei
Anna Ida Trolle
Nicolas Jonsson
Johannes Betz
Frederik E. Knudsen
Francesco Pesce
Kristoffer E. Johansson
Kresten Lindorff-Larsen

item.title: Top-predator recovery abates geomorphic decline of a coastal ecosystem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06959-9

Sea otters recolonizing an estuary in California indirectly reduce erosion by reducing burrowing crab abundance, suggesting that restoring predators could be a key mechanism to improve the stability of coastal wetlands and other ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Top-predator recovery abates geomorphic decline of a coastal ecosystem
item.dc:creator: Brent B. Hughes
Kathryn M. Beheshti
M. Tim Tinker
Christine Angelini
Charlie Endris
Lee Murai

Brian R. Silliman

item.title: Stress response silencing by an E3 ligase mutated in neurodegeneration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06985-7

The E3 ligase SIFI is identified as a dedicated silencing factor of the integrated stress response, a finding that has implications for the development of therapeutics for neurodegenerative diseases caused by mitochondrial protein import stress.
item.dc:title: Stress response silencing by an E3 ligase mutated in neurodegeneration
item.dc:creator: Diane L. Haakonsen
Michael Heider
Andrew J. Ingersoll
Kayla Vodehnal
Samuel R. Witus
Takeshi Uenaka
Marius Wernig
Michael Rapé

item.title: Durable CO<sub>2</sub> conversion in the proton-exchange membrane system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06917-5

We develop a proton-exchange membrane system that reduces CO2 to formic acid at a catalyst that is derived from waste lead–acid batteries and in which a lattice carbon activation mechanism contributes.
item.dc:title: Durable CO<sub>2</sub> conversion in the proton-exchange membrane system
item.dc:creator: Wensheng Fang

item.title: The Born in Guangzhou Cohort Study enables generational genetic discoveries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06988-4

Analysis of data from the Born in Guangzhou Cohort Study comprising mainly of trios and mother–infant pairs reveals novel East Asian-specific genetic associations with maternal bile acid, gestational weight gain and infant cord blood traits.
item.dc:title: The Born in Guangzhou Cohort Study enables generational genetic discoveries

item.title: SHR and SCR coordinate root patterning and growth early in the cell cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06971-z

Quantitative time-resolved microscopy analysis of SHR and SCR dynamics in single cells of living Arabidopsis roots shows that these transcription factors coordinate formative and proliferative cell divisions early in the cell cycle.
item.dc:title: SHR and SCR coordinate root patterning and growth early in the cell cycle
item.dc:creator: Cara M. Winter
Pablo Szekely
Vladimir Popov
Heather Belcher
Raina Carter
Matthew Jones

Thai V. Truong
Philip N. Benfey

item.title: Flexible silicon solar cells with high power-to-weight ratios
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06948-y

A study reports a combination of processing, optimization and low-damage deposition methods for the production of silicon heterojunction solar cells exhibiting flexibility and high performance.
item.dc:title: Flexible silicon solar cells with high power-to-weight ratios
item.dc:creator: Yang Li

item.title: 7-Dehydrocholesterol dictates ferroptosis sensitivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06983-9

7-Dehydrocholesterol (7-DHC) is a natural anti-ferroptotic metabolite and pharmacological manipulation of 7-DHC levels shows promise as a therapeutic strategy for cancer and ischaemia–reperfusion injury.
item.dc:title: 7-Dehydrocholesterol dictates ferroptosis sensitivity
item.dc:creator: Yaxu Li

item.title: High-quality semiconductor fibres via mechanical design
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06946-0

A mechanical design is developed for the fabrication of ultralong, fracture-free and perturbation-free semiconductor fibres to address the increasing demand for flexible and wearable optoelectronics.
item.dc:title: High-quality semiconductor fibres via mechanical design
item.dc:creator: Zhixun Wang
Zhe Wang
Dong Li
Chunlei Yang
Qichong Zhang
Ming Chen
Huajian Gao
Lei Wei

item.title: Ultracold field-linked tetratomic molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06986-6

Ultracold polyatomic molecules can be created by electroassociation in a degenerate Fermi gas of microwave-dressed polar molecules through a field-linked resonance.
item.dc:title: Ultracold field-linked tetratomic molecules
item.dc:creator: Xing-Yan Chen

Xin-Yu Luo

item.title: Designing a circular carbon and plastics economy for a sustainable future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06939-z

Four future greenhouse gas emission scenarios for the global plastics system are investigated, with the lead scenario achieving net-zero emissions, and a series of technical, legal and economic interventions recommended.
item.dc:title: Designing a circular carbon and plastics economy for a sustainable future
